Message.Msg: Ed Klein has previously discovered that Chelsea Clinton was conceived via Bill Clinton's rape of Hillary Clinton and that Hillary is a secret lesbian, so on all things Clinton, he is the go-to guy for groundbreaking scoops. Today he has another one about the Rumor That Will Never Die, a.k.a. the Great Switcheroo, in which Joe Biden is locked in the White House basement and replaced by Hillary Clinton on President Obama's reelection ticket. Everyone else is in the political-media world is just speculating, but Klein? Klein is reporting: "As recently as a couple of weeks ago, the White House was putting out feelers to see if Hillary Clinton was interested in replacing Joe Biden on the ticket," Klein told Secrets. "Bill Clinton, I'm told, was urging his wife to accept the number two spot if it was formally offered. Bill sees the vice presidency as the perfect launching pad for Hillary to run for president in 2016." ... Klein, whose book is No. 2 on the NYT bestseller list, quoted unnamed sources who revealed that top Obama aide Valerie Jarrett put the vice presidency on the table during a lunch with the secretary of state. "The lunch was ostensibly about policy issues, but the subject of the vice presidency came up," he said. "Hillary told Valerie Jarrett that she was not interested in running as Obama's vice president." http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/05/22/michael-tomasky-on-obama-s-hillary-clinton-joe-biden-switcheroo.html

Message.Title: The largest lie from the right is the housing issue.
Message.Msg: They blame the credit crisis on one of their favorite punching bags, fannie and freddie. There are soooooo many things wrong with this. 1 No credible economists agree that fan and fred were primary. 2 Fan and fred were miniscule compared to the loans issued, and to believe that wall street believed they had a way out through selling to fan and fred is like believing exxon mobil could always sell its gas to fred down the street if the world market tanked. 3 The financial wizardry being employed on wall street to value the loans relied on mathematical modeling that worked well as long as nobody blinked, their thinking is well documented in numerous books. 4 There was an illusion in place that real estate never declined and the cost of risky loans would be covered by asset appreciation. 5 The credit problems extended far beyond housing. 6 Other countries suffering under the same illusions had credit crashes without a fan or fred rescue even possible. 7 Massive inflows of money from China and trade imbalances together with classic synchronized speculation is the primary cause. But it is easier to blab out the talking points and augment the feeling 'I'm inteligunt' than to actually think. Type one thinking again.

Message.Title: The current monetary system will start to collapse in 2013 .......
Message.Msg: Most of the developed countries, US, UK, and Europe have carried so much debtload that the continued positive response cycle between economic growth and asset appreciation become almost impossible. US has about $16 trillion sovereign debt right not but it has more than $50 trillion liabilities on entitlement programs. I will show you that it is only Bernanke's pipe-dream to expect 3-4% real GDP growth over the next decade: (1) Based on the official fiscal deficit project up to 2020, the total US debtload is expected to reach $19-20 trillion. Given a 3% average interest rate on the debt, the total annual interest expense would be about $600 billion. This figure can goes to $1 trillion, if the average interest rate reaches 5%, which is not an likely scenario. ( This means that Federal Reserve will not boost the growth to much, assuming they still can, since 5% interest rate would mean almost immediate insolvent for the entire fiscal system.) (2) The most likely case is that we could see zero to negative average GDP growth over the next decades, with interest rate hovering around 1-2%. Why? Because Firstly, the healthcare industry would likely shrink 20%-30% given the much-needed reform. Currently, the most younger workers are enrolled in private health insurance program so that private providers could reap billions of profit; but the elders are kicked into the MediCare program, funded by the Tax Payers. Remember, 70% of average person's total life-time health cost is typically incurred during the last year of his/her life, i.e. when he/she is in MediCare program, funded by all the tax payers. Such system is no longer sustainable. Secondly, the traditional energy sector would likely shrink 30-70% over the next decade if the world government decide to adopt new technologies which can generate electricity from the vibration of particle from our ambient environment. If you do not believe me, search for kapanadze on the Internet. Such technologies and knowledge are hidden from us by the Elite for hundreds of years. That is why you have not heard about a inventor called Nikola Tesla, who have created many of things our life depend on nowadays. I understand that some groups' financial interest will be badly hurt by the wide application of such technologies. But I wonder how long the embargo against humanity would last. When the embargo is finally lifted, you might find your investment in tradition energy sector lose 50% of value immediately. These developments will lead to zero or negative GDP growth in the first decade as the economy realign itself. Unfortunately, it means that the current PONZI global monetary system will be essentially insolvent and could no longer sustainable. I do not how things will work out, but it would be very painful for many. However, the human kinds need such massive "reset" to embark on the neo-wave of sustainable development and prosperity. All you can do is to make yourself be prepared for the impact, since there will be many unknown unknowns.

Message.Title: Why Obama has to go - Newsweek
Message.Msg: Why does Paul Ryan scare the president so much? Because Obama has broken his promises, and it’s clear that the GOP ticket’s path to prosperity is our only hope. I was a good loser four years ago. “In the grand scheme of history,” I wrote the day after Barack Obama’s election as president, “four decades is not an especially long time. Yet in that brief period America has gone from the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. to the apotheosis of Barack Obama. You would not be human if you failed to acknowledge this as a cause for great rejoicing.” Despite having been—full disclosure—an adviser to John McCain, I acknowledged his opponent’s remarkable qualities: his soaring oratory, his cool, hard-to-ruffle temperament, and his near faultless campaign organization. Yet the question confronting the country nearly four years later is not who was the better candidate four years ago. It is whether the winner has delivered on his promises. And the sad truth is that he has not. Neal Ferguson
